prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: A motion before the Panel may be withdrawn by the moving party prior to submission or decision. This right is consistent with the general rules concerning withdrawal in motion practice in civil litigation.[1]

Withdrawal of a motion by a party is not, however, binding on the Panel. In one case the Panel issued an order to show cause why it should not enter the transfer order initially sought by a party in a motion which had been subsequently withdrawn.[2] Since the Panel can initiate transfer sua sponte, it can transfer even if a motion is withdrawn. The movant's right to withdraw a motion is also consistent with the Panel's practice of deeming an opposition to a conditional transfer order to be withdrawn if the party does not file a timely motion to vacate the conditional transfer order.[3]

Similarly, a motion can be amended. Although the Panel Rules do not specifically provide for amendment, parties do occasionally amend motions. Again, this Panel practice is consistent with general practice permitting amendment of motions in civil litigation.[4] Amendment of a motion to seek transfer of additional actions is an especially appropriate use of amendment. Such amendment does not prejudice any other party and facilitates the expeditious hearing of the positions of all parties. It also obviates entry of a conditional transfer for the later actions and holding a second hearing as to those actions.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 2.10 (8th ed. 2019).
See In re Yarn Processing Patent Validity Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 376, 377 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
See David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 2.9 & n.26 (8th ed. 2018).
